SEARCH
Package edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.hg

Class HeuristicGraph

java.lang.Object
edu.uky.cs.nil.sabre.hg.HeuristicGraph
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
MaxGraph, SumGraph
public abstract class HeuristicGraph extends Object implements Serializable
A heuristic graph is a data structure that represents the relationships between propositions and events in a ground problem to enable various kinds of analysis.

Heuristic graphs are inspired by Avrim Blum and Merrick Furst's plan graph data structure. It represents a relaxed model of a planning problem where once a proposition becomes true it stays true forever (sometimes called the "ignore delete lists" relaxation). However, these are several important differences:

  • Since Sabre problems use fluents and are not limited to Boolean propositions, heuristic graphs represent each fluent as a set of values where values can be added to the set but never removed (sometimes called monotonic or accumulating semantics).
  • Heuristic graphs can represent numeric values, like numeric fluents and arithmetic expressions. By default, numeric values are represented as a range which implicitly includes all values between the lowest and highest value.
  • A heuristic graph does not model mutex relations. This is because mutex relations are costly to check, and heuristic graphs are designed to be fast enough to be reused frequently, such as in Jorg Hoffmann's Fast Forward heuristic.
  • Heuristic graphs generalize Blum and Furst's plan graphs as well as Blai Bonet and Hector Geffner's additive heuristic by allowing multiple possible definitions of a node's cost. A max graph is a heuristic graph where the cost of a conjunction is the maximum cost of any of its conjuncts, similar to the levels of Blum and Furst's plan graph. A sum graph is a heuristic graph where the cost of a conjunction is the sum of the cost of its conjuncts (similar to Bonet and Geffner's additive heuristic).
Nodes in a heuristic graph can be treated like a monotonically increasing set of values that are each associated with a cost. The most common operation on a heuristic graph is to query a node about the cost of a value. For example, you can ask a nominal fluent how much it would cost for it to take on one of its many possible values. When a heuristic graph is initialized to a state, every value will have either a cost of 0 (meaning the node's expression has that value in the initial state) or positive infinity (meaning the node's expression cannot yet have that value). Each time a heuristic graph is extended, every action whose precondition has a finite cost will be added to the graph (that is, its cost will go from infinite to finite). Adding new actions may cause new expressions that previously had an infinite cost to have a finite cost. If those new actions enable new propositions, then extending the graph again may add new actions, and those actions will add new propositions, and so on. Eventually, the graph will level off, which means that no new actions can be added. Once a graph has leveled off, extend() will return false.

Some nodes represent Boolean propositions, whose sets of values can only be true and false. Examples include disjunctions, clauses, preconditions, and effects. These nodes only have a CostNode.getCost() method that returns the cost of that expression being true. Event nodes are like this too; their CostNode.getCost() method returns the cost of reaching a state where that event could occur.

Heuristic graphs can be used to explore the structural properties of a problem, such as which actions can possibly satisfy certain propositions. Heuristic graphs can also be used to check a necessary but not sufficient condition for whether a proposition is possible. Once a heuristic graph has leveled off, if a proposition is not in the graph, we can be confident that the proposition is impossible (however, we cannot be certain that a proposition is possible just because it is in the graph).

Heuristic graphs are commonly used to simplify compiled problems and in heuristics for heuristic search.

Author:
Stephen G. Ware

    HeuristicGraph(CompiledProblem problem, Worker.Status status)
    Constructs a heuristic graph which contains nodes for every fluent, event, and utility in a given problem.

    Constructs a heuristic graph which contains only the nodes representing false, true, and the empty clause.

    Defines the cost of an effect node being included in the graph, which means that at least one of the events that has this effect has a finite cost and the effect's condition also has a finite cost.

    cost(EffectNode node, Value value, double cost)
    Defines the cost of an effect node's fluent having a given value from the right hand side of an effect node's assignment based on the value and cost of the right hand side.
    protected abstract double
    cost(GoalNode node, Value value, double cost)
    Defines the cost of a utility node having a given value based on the cost of the goal condition that was met and the value and cost of the branch of the utility expression that was evaluated.
    protected abstract double

    Defines the cost of a precondition node being true based on the values and costs of the left and right sides of its comparison.

    extend()
    Sets the cost of any action node which currently has an infinite cost but whose precondition has a finite cost to the cost of its precondition plus one.

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Overrides:

    • getNode

      public Node getNode(Logical logical)
      Returns the heuristic graph node associated with the given logical expression. If the node does not exist, it will be created.
      Parameters:
      logical - the logical expression to represent in the graph
      Returns:
      a node representing that logical expression (which will have that expression as its its label)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the graph cannot create a node for the given expression
      FormatException - if the logical expression is not ground

    • makeRange

      protected Range makeRange(Expression expression)
      This method is used to create all ranges in the graph so that subclasses of HeuristicGraph have the option to return subclasses of Range to modify the graph's behavior. By default, this method calls makeNumericRange() for all numeric expressions, and makeNominalRange() for all other expressions.
      Parameters:
      expression - the logical expression whose set of values will be represented by the range
      Returns:
      a range object representing the possible values of the logical expression

    • makeNominalRange

      protected Range makeNominalRange()
      This method is used to create all nominal ranges (that is, range objects that hold a set of discrete values) so that subclasses of HeuristicGraph have the option to return subclasses of Range to modify the graph's behavior. By default, this method returns a new ArrayRange.
      Returns:
      a range object representing the possible values of a logical expression that has discrete nominal values

    • makeNumericRange

      protected Range makeNumericRange()
      This method is used to create all numeric ranges (that is, range objects that hold a potentially infinite set of numeric values) so that subclasses of HeuristicGraph have the option to return subclasses of DisjunctionNode to modify the graph's behavior. By default, this method returns a new InfiniteSpan.
      Returns:
      a range object representing the possible values of a logical expression that has discrete nominal values

      Returns the constant node associated with the given logical value. If the node does not exist, it will be created.
      Parameters:
      value - the logical value to represent in the graph
      Returns:
      a constant node representing that value

    • cost

      protected abstract double cost(ArithmeticNode node, Value leftValue, double leftCost, Value rightValue, double rightCost)
      Defines the cost of a value of an arithmetic node based on the values and costs of the left and right sides of the node's arithmetic expression.
      Parameters:
      node - the arithmetic node for which the cost of a value is being calculated
      leftValue - the value of the left side of the arithmetic expression
      leftCost - the cost of the value on the left side
      rightValue - the value of the right side of the arithmetic expression
      rightCost - the cost of the value on the right side
      Returns:
      the cost of the value that results from evaluating the node's arithmetic expression with the given left and right side values

    • cost

      protected abstract double cost(PreconditionNode node, Value leftValue, double leftCost, Value rightValue, double rightCost)
      Defines the cost of a precondition node being true based on the values and costs of the left and right sides of its comparison. This method will only be called with values that make the precondition evaluate to true.
      Parameters:
      node - the precondition node for which the cost of being true is being calculated
      leftValue - the value on the left side of the comparison
      leftCost - the cost of the value on the left
      rightValue - the value on the right side of the comparison
      rightCost - the cost of the value on the right
      Returns:
      the cost of the precondition being true with the given left and right values

    • cost

      protected abstract double cost(ClauseNode node)
      Defines the cost of a clause node being true. The preconditions that make up the clause and their costs can be accessed from the node itself. This method will be called after ClauseNode.notify(Node, Value, double) has been called as many times as it has preconditions. Usually, this implies this method will not be called until all preconditions in the clause have a finite cost, but this cannot be guaranteed.
      Parameters:
      node - the clause node for which the cost of bring true is being calculated
      Returns:
      the cost of a clause being true

    • cost

      protected abstract double cost(EffectNode node)
      Defines the cost of an effect node being included in the graph, which means that at least one of the events that has this effect has a finite cost and the effect's condition also has a finite cost. The events that have this effect and the condition can be accessed from the node itself. This method may be called before some event has a finite cost and before the condition has a finite cost.
      Parameters:
      node - the effect node for which the cost of being true is being calculated
      Returns:
      the cost of the effect being true

    • cost

      protected abstract double cost(EffectNode node, Value value, double cost)
      Defines the cost of an effect node's fluent having a given value from the right hand side of an effect node's assignment based on the value and cost of the right hand side.
      Parameters:
      node - the effect node which is assigning the value to its fluent
      value - the value being assigned to the fluent
      cost - the cost of the value being assigned to the fluent
      Returns:
      the cost of the fluent having that value

    • getCharacters

      public Iterable<Character> getCharacters()
      Returns the characters which have utility nodes represented in the graph. The resulting collection will not include null, even if the author's utility is represented.
      Returns:
      a collection of characters whose utilities are defined in the graph

    • getUtility

      public UtilityNode getUtility()
      Returns the utility node representing the author's utility if it has been defined.
      Returns:
      a utility node representing the author's utility, or null if the author's utility has not been represented in this graph yet

    • getUtility

      public UtilityNode getUtility(Character character)
      Returns the utility node representing an character's utility if it has been defined.
      Parameters:
      character - the character whose utility representation is desired
      Returns:
      a utility node representing the character's utility, or null if the character's utility has not been represented in this graph yet

    • setUtility

      public UtilityNode setUtility(Character character, Conditional<Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>>> utility)
      Defines a utility node for the given character using the given utility expression. To define the author's utility, the character argument should be null. This method should only be called once per character; calling it more than once per character will cause an IllegalStateException. To access an already defined utility node, use getUtility().
      Parameters:
      character - the character whose utility is being represented
      utility - a numeric expression which can be evaluated to determine how satisfied the character is with a given situation
      Returns:
      a utility node for that character representing the utility expression
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if a utility node has already been defined for the character

    • makeUtilityNode

      protected UtilityNode makeUtilityNode(Character character, Conditional<Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>>> conditional)
      This method is used to create all utility nodes so that subclasses of HeuristicGraph have the option to return subclasses of UtilityNode to modify the graph's behavior.
      Parameters:
      character - the character whose utility is being defined
      conditional - a numeric expression which can be evaluated to determine how satisfied the character is with a given situation
      Returns:
      a new utility node

    • makeGoalNode

      protected GoalNode makeGoalNode(UtilityNode utility, Conditional<Disjunction<Clause<Precondition>>> label)
      This method is used to create all goal nodes so that subclasses of HeuristicGraph have the option to return subclasses of GoalNode to modify the graph's behavior.
      Parameters:
      utility - the utility node for which this goal represents a branch
      label - a conditional expression where the first condition and branch (and only the first condition and branch) will be used as the condition and value expressions for one branch of a utility node
      Returns:
      a goal node for the given utility node with the given condition

    • cost

      protected abstract double cost(GoalNode node, Value value, double cost)
      Defines the cost of a utility node having a given value based on the cost of the goal condition that was met and the value and cost of the branch of the utility expression that was evaluated. A utility node has has many goals, which represent the conditions and branches of a conditional utility expression. When a goal node's condition becomes finite, it becomes possible for the goal's utility node to take on every value that the goal node's value expression can have. This method will only be called after the goal node has a finite cost.
      Parameters:
      node - the goal node which represents a condition of the utility expression that has a finite cost
      value - a value that the goal node's value expression can have
      cost - the cost of the goal node's value expression having that value
      Returns:
      the cost of the goal node's utility node having that value

    • reset

      public void reset()
      Resets event node in the graph so that all costs are positive infinity, except for costs which are trivially 0 (the constant node representing true and the clause node representing the empty clause).

    • getLevels

      public double[] getLevels()
      Returns an array of all finite costs that appear anywhere in the graph (that is, the cost of any cost nodes with a finite cost and the costs of any cost sets that have values with finite costs).
      Returns:
      a sorted array of finite costs that appear in this graph

    • initialize

      public void initialize(State state)
      Resets all nodes in the graph and then initializes all fluent nodes by setting the cost of the value that fluent has in the given state to 0. After initialization, nodes that represent Boolean propositions will have a cost of 0 if they are true in the given state or positive infinity otherwise. Numeric nodes like arithmetic nodes and utility nodes will have the cost of their value in the given state set of 0, and the cost of all other values set to positive infinity.
      Parameters:
      state - the state that defines the initial value of each fluent

    • extend

      public boolean extend()
      Sets the cost of any action node which currently has an infinite cost but whose precondition has a finite cost to the cost of its precondition plus one. This method returns true if at least one new action was assigned a finite cost; otherwise, this method returns false. Once this method returns false, the heuristic graph is said to have leveled off.
      Returns:
      true if at least one action that previously has an infinite cost was assigned a finite cost, or false if the graph has leveled off
